content.description: Just right of the obvious right facing corner (Gastonia Crack).  For full effect start at the crack that diagonals up and right. Climb to a good rest at the prominent horizontal. Sidepull off of an awkward knob in the thin seam above (crux). Continue up the seam to a large ledge 10 feet below the anchors.
content.protection: usually toproped. You can load up the horizontal with mid-sized cams for the runout above the crux.

content.description: Climb the crack right of Mikes Crack and So It Goes. Fun introduction to traditional climbing route or an easy top rope set-up for beginning climbers.
content.protection: Trad Rack. Small to Medium gear.
content.location: Hike up the Backside Trail and when you arrive at the top of the stairs there are three sets of anchors. Facing East (towards Charlotte) the anchor is the one on the left next to the tree.

content.description: Right of Mike's Crack, climb the shallow cracks and face to the top.
Just right of Burn Crack.  Climb the overhanging face to a rounded flake.  Pass 2 bolts and head right, fighting the pump and up to the top.
content.protection: small gear.  the 2 bolts used to be pitons.
content.location: At left end of cliff, just right of obvious Burn crack.

content.description: Climb the crux of BFD and then traverse left on ancient pitons through a crux to finish on SSSS.
content.location: Start on Black flag Direct. Follow seam to left just past crux. Ends on SSSS.

content.description: Climb the face right of Gastonia Crack(5.4)
content.protection: Great trad beginner route, lots of gear options. Bolted anchor.
content.location: Located at Practice Wall. Mostly Top-Roped but an great trad climb for beginning trad climbers.

content.description: This route starts easy, but gets harder than the 5.5 rating suggests.  The crack is easy, but the move out to the face can prove difficult (especially if committed to the crack).  Not a bad route.
content.protection: Easily top-roped.  Big gear for the bottom, smaller for the top (if you want to lead).
content.location: The route is a left facing dihedral-type-thing.  It's a big crack toward the right side of the practice wall.

content.description:
I've never seen anyone attempt this on lead or top rope. I was told that this route went up as an AID route before being freed (cool tidbit of history).

Start on Slimebelly Snakeass Sodhole Skunkpie(5.12a). Traverse cliff right on the low horizontal crack system (past two fixed pins) connecting on to Black Flag Direct(5.13b) and finishing up on Black Flag(5.10d).
content.protection:
Top Rope set up.

Trad Rack.

content.description: Climb the arete left of Gastonia Crack(5.4). An overhung flake is the first crux leading to a good ledge to traverse cliff right onto the arete. This is the second crux that leads straight up the arete to a slabby mantle top out. Once on the ledge climb the 'boulder' left on the platform. Top out and scramble to the bolted anchor for (Gastonia Crack and Playground).
content.protection: North Carolina Trad Rack, share the bolted anchor with Gastonia Crack and Playground. Kind of hard to top rope without a directional on the 'boulder' finish.
content.location:
Right of Black Flag(5.10)

Left of Gastonia Crack(5.4)

content.description: This is a fun route as either a first or last climb of the day.  Since it's at the terminus of the trail, access is easy.  It offers fun climbing on big holds.
content.protection: Easily top-roped.  If you want to lead it, a nice variety of gear will fit, however, it would probably tend to be on the bigger side.  Two bolts serve as anchors.
content.location: The route is easily identifiable as the right-facing dihedral right in the middle of the Practice wall.

content.description: Boulder up the powerful overhanging opening moves to some finger jugs at the base of the crack.  Do a couple jam moves and mantle up on a small ledge.  Only a few more face moves separate you from the top.  Walk off.
content.protection: NC trad, cams up to 3 Camalot.
content.location: At left end of Practice Wall, just left of Skunkpie.  It is the only crack.

content.description:
This is also a popular top-rope but is somewhat harder than its brother (The Wall) next door.

For the most part, this info came from Lambert's and Shull's Selected Climbs in North Carolina.
content.protection: Set up as a top rope climb

content.description:
Mostly top roped. This route is missing the hanger on the first bolt.

Locate the bolt with no hanger. Climb to the horizontal and traverse slightly cliff right connecting on to the Black Flag crack system with the last bolt for this route. Pull the roof to the two bolt anchor.
content.protection:
Tope Rope set up.

NC Trad Rack, quickdraws, and a spare hanger for the first bolt if you plan to lead it.
content.location: The left side of Practice Wall. In the overhung section.

content.description: Start on the arete and face just left of Gastonia Crack. Traverse across the horizontal with an old pin in it.  Hard moves to a bolt at a 'stance'. Rest up here and climb through the roof to the top anchors

It has a couple of tricky spots with body position about 15 feet up then traversers over to the left and shares the chains with Brick in the Wall.

For the most part, this info came from Lambert's and Shull's Selected Climbs in North Carolina.
content.location: Between Brick in the Wall on the left and Mike's Crack on the right
